title: Can I file bankruptcy even if I am on temporary work permit in US ?
question: Hi,
answers:
As long as you live in the US, you are eligible to file a bankruptcy. However, you are required to list all assets you own, even if they are located outside of the US.

Hope this perspective helps!

As long as you own property or a business in the U.S., you’re eligible for bankruptcy relief. However, many Courts disagree as to what “property in the United States” means. Simply having mailbox or bank account might not be enough for some Courts.

Also, as was correctly pointed out, the U.S. Trustee will have rights to all your property wherever it may be, including in your home country. But, a U.S. bankruptcy will not wipe out any foreign debts. So, foreign debtors who owe debts in their own country will find that the U.S. discharge did not affect them. I second the opinion on getting a sophisticated bankruptcy attorney.

It is often hard for a Chapter 7 Trustee's to know what interest a debtor may have under applicable foreign law in a piece of personal or real property; they are a suspicious lot by necessity. Sometimes its best to obtain local counsel in your country to document what you own and to articulate the nature of the interest in a manner that will be clear and concise. However, that can be expensive.

Best of luck.

You do not need to be a U.S. citizen to file a bankruptcy case. However, all your assets, wherever located on the planet are subject to the control of your U.S. bankruptcy trustee. If you have assets in a foreign country and are thinking of bankruptcy, locate the most sophisticated bankruptcy attorney you can find to handle the matter. Assets in exotic locations are like a red flag before a trustee and things can get very complicated very fast.
